title: Introduction to prioritization
text: Continuous values often need standardized 0-100 scale can weighted combined. can using s_standardize(). function supports two scaling methods: "observe" (scaling purely based local minimum maximum dataset) "benchmark" (scaling based absolute reference values provide).
code: # A simple vector of costs costs <- c(150, 200, 350, 500)  # Observe method (relative scaling) s_standardize(costs, selected_method = "observe") #> [1]   0.00000  14.28571  57.14286 100.00000  # Benchmark method (absolute scaling against limits of 0 and 1000) s_standardize(costs, selected_method = "benchmark",                min_bound = 0, max_bound =1000) #> [1] 15 20 35 50

title: Introduction to prioritization
text: assembling spatial score, need configuration data.frame mapping variable behaviors (direction, weights, standardization bounds). can generate mapping directly raw dataset using s_config(). resulting configuration table can used downstream spatial prioritization scripts ensure spatial layers standardized aggregated correctly.
code: # Suppose we have dataset with population and infrastructure cost planning_data <- data.frame(   pop_density = c(10, 50, 100, 20),   cost = c(500, 1500, 800, 1000) )  # Tell the config that higher population is better, but lower cost is better my_config <- s_config(   planning_data,   direction = c("larger is better", "smaller is better") )  my_config #>                      id        name   group weight         direction  method #> pop_density pop_density pop_density general      1  larger is better observe #> cost               cost        cost general      1 smaller is better observe #>             min  max #> pop_density  10  100 #> cost        500 1500

title: Create a config data frame — s_config
text: Creates standardized configuration data frame provided data frame sf object. config table intended multi-criteria evaluation workflows.

title: Create a config data frame — s_config
code: s_config(   x,   name = NA,   group = NA,   weight = NA,   direction = NA,   method = NA,   min = NA,   max = NA )

title: Create a config data frame — s_config
text: x data.frame sf object. sf, geometry might need dropped first depending workflow. name Human-friendly names variable x. Defaults column names x. group character vector grouping variable column x. Defaults single "general" group. weight numeric vector weights passed weighted mean. vector might single number vector length number columns x. Defaults 1. direction character vector stating variable x considers "larger better" "smaller better". Defaults "smaller better". method character vector stating standardization method "observe" "benchmark". Defaults "observe". min numeric vector representing minimum value considered "benchmark" method. Defaults calculated minimum value column x. max numeric vector representing maximum value considered "benchmark" method. Defaults calculated maximum value column x.

title: Create a config data frame — s_config
text: data.frame row represents configuration single variable (column) x. data frame contains following columns: id, name, weight, direction, method, min, max.

title: Create a config data frame — s_config
code: # Use a sample data frame to create the config table sample_data <- data.frame(   population = c(100, 200, 300),   cost = c(500, 100, 250) )  # Create a default config s_config(sample_data) #>                    id       name   group weight         direction  method min #> population population population general      1 smaller is better observe 100 #> cost             cost       cost general      1 smaller is better observe 100 #>            max #> population 300 #> cost       500  # Create a custom config indicating 'cost' is smaller is better s_config(   sample_data,   direction = c("larger is better", "smaller is better") ) #>                    id       name   group weight         direction  method min #> population population population general      1  larger is better observe 100 #> cost             cost       cost general      1 smaller is better observe 100 #>            max #> population 300 #> cost       500

what: Standardize a vector of numeric values — s_standardize
title: Standardize a vector of numeric values — s_standardize
text: Standardizes numeric vector using either "observe" method (scaling based vector's empirical min max) "benchmark" method (scaling based user-supplied reference min max bounds). Values scaled 0 100 range.

title: Standardize a vector of numeric values — s_standardize
code: s_standardize(   x,   selected_method = "observe",   min_bound = NULL,   max_bound = NULL )

title: Standardize a vector of numeric values — s_standardize
text: x numeric vector standardize. selected_method character string indicating scaling method. Must either "observe" (default) "benchmark". min_bound numeric value representing minimum reference bound. Required selected_method "benchmark". Default NULL. max_bound numeric value representing maximum reference bound. Required selected_method "benchmark". Default NULL.

title: Standardize a vector of numeric values — s_standardize
text: numeric vector length x, values scaled lie 0 100.

title: Standardize a vector of numeric values — s_standardize
code: # "benchmark" as selected method s_standardize(   x = c(0, 50, 100, 200),   selected_method = "benchmark",   min_bound = 0,   max_bound = 100 ) #> [1]   0  50 100 100  # "observe" as selected method s_standardize(   x = c(-100, 50, 100, 200),   selected_method = "observe" ) #> [1]   0.00000  50.00000  66.66667 100.00000
